newsitem.title: ISRAEL: EU parliament chief favours Palestinian trade deal.
newsitem.headline: EU parliament chief favours Palestinian trade deal.

text.p: The president of the European Parliament said on Wednesday he looks forward to the signing of an association agreement between the Palestinian Authority and the European Union.

In his first address to the Palestinian Legislative Council, Klaus Hansch endorsed Palestinian aspirations for independence and urged Israel to implement "to the letter" self-rule agreements it signed with the Palestinian Authority.

"The European Parliament welcomes the trade and cooperation agreement already under negotiation between the Union and the Palestinian Authority," Hansch told the 88-member council in the West Bank town of Ramallah.
"And we look forward to the day when it becomes an association agreement," he said.

The European Union (EU) is currently negotiating a trade cooperation agreement to include the Palestinian Authority in the so-called Euromed accord, which governs the 15-nation bloc's relations with Mediterranean partners. The agreement could be finalised by the end of 1996.
The EU signed an association agreement with Israel earlier this year.
Hansch reiterated the EU's support for Palestinian statehood and its commitment to Israel's right to live within secure boundaries.
The European Union, the largest donor to Palestinian self-rule areas, is seeking a more prominent role in peacemaking alongside the United States.
In October, French President Jacques Chirac became the first foreign head of state to address the Palestinian Legislative Council.
